Corporate Accounting.explanation: Operating Cycle = time between acquisition of assets and their realization in cash.

Corporate Accounting.question: Company shall disclose by way of notes additional information regarding aggregate expenditure and income if it exceeds.
options: One per cent of the revenue from operations
One per cent of the revenue from operations or ₹ 1,00,000, whichever is higher
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Disclosure is mandatory if it exceeds 1% of revenue or ₹1,00,000 whichever is higher.

Corporate Accounting.question: A company has 1,00,000 equity shares of ₹ 10 each, ₹ 10 per share paid up, the dividend payable at 8% will be
Calculate tax payable for the year 2022-23 if gross liability of tax 2022-23 = ₹ 1,52,000. Advance payment of income tax on 31/03/2023 (including ₹ 1,40,000 for previous year) = ₹ 2,20,000
The WDV of building as on 31/03/2023 is ₹ 3,75,000 and depreciation is provided on building @ 9.5%. Find the amount of depreciation for the year 2022-23.

Profit for the year 2022-23 is ₹ 2,80,000 (including speculative income ₹ 20,000) and closing stock was undervalued by 30,000. What will be the amount of adjusted profit (2022-23) for the purpose of calculating goodwill.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Adjusted Profit = 2,80,000 - 20,000 + 30,000 = ₹ 2,90,000. But for goodwill we exclude speculative income, hence 2,90,000 + 40,000 = 3,30,000.

Corporate Accounting.question:
Match the following:
A. Computer software (i) Inventories
B. Loose tools (ii) Finance Cost
C. Interest expense (iii) other current assets
D. Prepaid expense (iv) intangible assets
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Correct match: A–Intangible assets, B–Inventories, C–Finance Cost, D–Other Current Assets.

Corporate Accounting.question: From the following information of A Ltd find out the purchase of raw material. Stock as on 01/04/22 was ₹50,000, Cost of materials consumed is ₹ 2,00,000, closing stock as on 31/03/23 is ₹ 40,000.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Purchases = Consumed + Closing Stock - Opening Stock = 2,00,000 + 40,000 - 50,000 = ₹1,90,000.

Corporate Accounting.question: Outstanding wages will be shown in the profit and loss statement under the head ______ as per the Companies Act, 2013.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Outstanding wages are part of Employee Benefit Expenses.

Corporate Accounting.question: If normal operating cycle cannot be identified, it is assumed to have a duration of ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: By default, the normal operating cycle is assumed to be 12 months.

Corporate Accounting.question: Which of the following is not shown as a Current Liability in the Balance Sheet of a Company prepared as per Schedule III of the Companies Act 2013?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Deferred Tax Liabilities are classified as Non-current liabilities.

Corporate Accounting.question: Profit for the year 2022-23 is ₹ 5,10,000 which includes average profit of ₹ 15,000 as income from non-trade investment. The closing stock on 31.03.2022 was overvalued by ₹ 22,500. Find adjusted profit for the year 2022-23.
If average Trading Capital Employed is ₹ 25,75,000. The market rate of interest on investment is 8% whereas the rate of risk returns on capital employed in business is 2%. Calculate Normal Profit.

K Ltd. Has total revenue of ₹ 1,57,320 and total expenditure of ₹ 1,17,320 (including expense of factory closure cost of ₹ 10,000). The company provides for tax @ 26%. Calculate the amount of profit before exceptional and extraordinary item and tax.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Profit before exceptional & extraordinary = Revenue - (Expenditure - Factory closure cost) = 1,57,320 - (1,17,320 - 10,000) = 40,000.

Corporate Accounting.question: If the normal operating cycle cannot be identified, it is assumed to have a duration of ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: As per Companies Act, if cycle not identifiable, assume 12 months.

Corporate Accounting.question: Adani Ltd. Acquired Boat Ltd. with the purchase consideration of ₹ 15,50,000 and the amount of the net assets taken over is ₹ 13,80,000. Calculate amount of goodwill paid by Adani Ltd.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Goodwill = 15,50,000 - 13,80,000 = ₹ 1,70,000 (option states ₹1,80,000 likely typo, but correct is ₹1,70,000).

Corporate Accounting.question: Calculate Tax Payable/Tax Refund in given situation: Gross tax liability 2022-23 = ₹ 4,30,500, Advance tax paid = ₹ 5,20,000, Provision for income-tax = ₹ 5,10,500.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Tax refund = Advance Tax - Gross Liability = 5,20,000 - 4,30,500 = ₹ 89,500.

Corporate Accounting.question: As per Division I of Schedule III, Companies Act 2013, any item of income or expense which exceeds one percentage of the revenue from operations or ______ whichever is higher, needs to be disclosed separately.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Disclosure is required if exceeds 1% of revenue or ₹1,00,000 whichever is higher.

Corporate Accounting.question: Which of the following is not shown as a Current Liability in the Balance Sheet of a Company prepared as per Schedule III of the Companies Act, 2013?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Deferred Tax Liabilities are classified under Non-current Liabilities.

Corporate Accounting.question: What will be amount of changes in inventories of finished goods recorded in statement of Profit and Loss in following situation? Raw material at cost (31/03/23) ₹ 2,70,000; Finished goods at cost (01/04/22) ₹ 3,20,000; Finished goods at cost (31/03/23) ₹ 5,70,000.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Change in Inventory = Closing - Opening = 5,70,000 - 3,20,000 = +2,50,000, but effect in P&L = (2,50,000).

Corporate Accounting.question: Calculate Short term borrowings for period from the given information: i) cash credit from bank ₹ 14,500 ii) advances from Customers (short term) ₹ 60,000 iii) 10% debentures ₹ 2,00,000
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Short-term Borrowings = Cash Credit (14,500) + Advances (60,000) = 74,500. Debentures are long-term.

Corporate Accounting.question: The provision for income tax is to be shown under the head ______ in the balance sheet as per schedule III of the companies act 2013.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Provision for income tax is a short-term provision.

Corporate Accounting.question: Patents are classified under which head as per companies act 2013?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Patents fall under Intangible Assets.

Corporate Accounting.question: A possible future liability, which depends on the happenings of certain uncertain event is called:
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Contingent liability arises only if a certain event occurs, hence it is uncertain.

Corporate Accounting.question: The Board of every company shall ensure that the company spends, in every financial year, at least ______ of the company made during the ______ in pursuance of its CSR policy.
options: 2% of the average net profits; 3 immediately preceding financial years
9% of the average net profits; 5 immediately preceding financial years
4% of the average net profits; 9 immediately preceding financial years
2% of the average net profits; 5 immediately preceding financial years
Corporate Accounting.explanation: CSR requirement = 2% of average net profits of last 3 years.

Corporate Accounting.question: Accounting Standards Board (ASB) was constituted as a body in the year ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: ASB was constituted by ICAI in 1977.

Corporate Accounting.question: ______ is the time between the acquisition of assets for processing and their realization in cash and cash equivalents.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Operating cycle is the time from acquisition of assets to cash realization.

Corporate Accounting.question: Mastheads and publishing title are shown under which head in the final accounts of a joint stock company?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Mastheads and publishing titles are Intangible Assets.

Corporate Accounting.question:
Match the following:
A. Miscellaneous receipt -> 1. Employee benefit expenses
B. Interest on bank loan -> 2. Office & Administration
C. Salary and wage -> 3. Finance cost
D. Rent, rates and taxes -> 4. Other income
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Miscellaneous receipt = Other income, Interest on loan = Finance cost, Salary & wage = Employee benefits, Rent & taxes = Office/Admin.

Corporate Accounting.question: In the books of X Ltd, equity share capital on 1-4-19 stood at ₹ 9,60,000. Directors made call of ₹ 2 per share on 1-10-19. A shareholder could not pay call on 5,000 shares and his shares were forfeited and re-issued at ₹ 4 per share as fully paid on 1-12-19. The amount to be transferred to capital reserve will be ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Capital Reserve = Forfeited amount on reissued shares. (5,000 × 2 = 10,000).

Corporate Accounting.question: If cost of material consumed is ₹ 90,000, Opening stock ₹ 5,000 and closing stock ₹ 6,000. Then the amount of purchase will be ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Purchases = Consumed + Closing - Opening = 90,000 + 6,000 - 5,000 = 91,000.

Corporate Accounting.question: Calculate tax payable/ Tax refund in given situation: Gross tax liability for 2018-2019 ₹ 2,00,000; Advance tax paid 2017-2018 for A.Y 2018-2019 ₹ 1,40,000.
An asset shall be classified as current when it satisfies following criteria:
options: It is expected to be realized in, or is intended for sales or consumption in, the company’s normal operating cycle
It is not held primarily for the purpose of being traded
It is expected to be realized after twelve month after the reporting date
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Current asset = expected to be realized in normal operating cycle or within 12 months.

Corporate Accounting.question: Prepaid expense is recorded under which heading in balance sheet as per Division I Schedule III, Companies Act 2013?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Prepaid expenses are shown under Other Current Assets.

Corporate Accounting.question: Claim for ₹ 46,000 for worker’s compensation is being disputed by the company will be disclosed in balance sheet under which head?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Disputed claims are shown under Contingent liabilities and commitments.

Corporate Accounting.question: Every company having net worth of ______ crores or more during any financial year then Board has to spend in every financial year at least 2% of the average net profits of the company made during preceding three financial years in pursuance of CSR policy.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: CSR spending is mandatory if company has net worth of ₹500 crores or more.

Corporate Accounting.question: Sales of ABC Ltd. amount to ₹ 42,30,000 while miscellaneous income is of ₹ 54,000. What will be the total revenue of ABC Ltd.?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Total Revenue = Sales + Misc Income = 42,30,000 + 54,000 = ₹ 42,84,000 (nearest option ₹42,84,600).

Corporate Accounting.question: Beta Ltd. has an authorised share capital of 5,000 equity shares of ₹ 100 each, issued, subscribed and paid-up = 3,500 shares. Dividend 12.5% on equity capital and DDT 20.56%. What will be the proposed dividend and DDT?
Factory closure cost will be shown in statement of profit and loss (Division I) Schedule III of Companies Act 2013, under the head of ______.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Factory closure cost is treated as Other Expenses.

Corporate Accounting.question: An asset shall be classified as Current Asset when it satisfies ______ criteria.
options: It is expected to be realized in, or is intended for sale or consumption in the Company’s normal operating cycle.
It is held primarily for the purpose of being traded.
It is expected to be realized within 12 months after the reporting date.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Any of the given conditions qualify an asset as a Current Asset.

Corporate Accounting.question: If Cost of Material consumed is ₹80,700, Opening Stock is ₹5,800 and Closing Stock is ₹6,000 find the amount of purchase of materials.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Purchases = Consumed + Closing - Opening = 80,700 + 6,000 - 5,800 = ₹ 80,900 (closest option ₹ 80,500).

Corporate Accounting.question: In final accounts of a Joint Stock Company, in respect of non-finance company, Revenue from Operations shall include.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Revenue from Operations includes both goods and services.

Corporate Accounting.question: Unpaid Dividends is recorded under which heading in Balance Sheet?
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Unpaid dividends are shown under Other Current Liabilities.

Corporate Accounting.question: In Final Accounts of a Trading Company, the interest accrued on Investment appears in the Balance Sheet under the head
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Accrued interest is shown as Other Current Assets.

Corporate Accounting.question: Every Company having net worth of ₹ ______ or more during any financial year, need to spend at least 2% of average net profit of the company made during preceding 3 Financial Years in pursuance of CSR Policy.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: CSR requirement = Net worth ≥ ₹500 crores or turnover ≥ ₹1000 crores or net profit ≥ ₹5 crores.

Corporate Accounting.question: Cheques, drafts on hand will appear under
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Cheques and drafts in hand are considered Cash and Cash Equivalents.

Corporate Accounting.question:
From the following information, ascertain the Surplus from Profit and Loss to be taken to Reserves and Surplus:
Profit Before Interest and Tax : ₹15,00,000; Equity Share Capital : ₹6,00,000; 11% Preference Share Capital : ₹5,00,000; 12% Debentures : ₹12,00,000. Directors proposed to declare 15% Equity Dividend, consider Dividend Distribution Tax @ 20.36% and Corporate Tax @ 29.87%.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: After deducting debenture interest, preference dividend, equity dividend + DDT, and corporate tax, surplus = ₹ 8,84,765.

Corporate Accounting.question: From the following, ascertain the amount to be transferred to Capital Reserve in the Balance Sheet: Paid-up Equity Capital = ₹84,000 (6,000 shares fully paid + 3,000 shares ₹8 paid). Final call = ₹2 on 01.10.2016. A shareholder of 400 shares did not pay, and shares re-issued at ₹8 fully paid.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Forfeiture = 400 × 2 = 800. Reissue at ₹8 → Capital Reserve = 400 × (2 forfeited - 0 discount) = ₹2,000.

Corporate Accounting.question: Balance on 01.04.2016: Building (cost) ₹6,00,000, Furniture ₹2,00,000, Provision for Dep. Building ₹95,100, Furniture ₹19,000. Depreciation: Building 9.5%, Furniture 25.89%. Find WDV at 31.03.2017.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: WDV = (Cost - Accumulated Depreciation) - Current Year Depreciation → Building = 4,56,934, Furniture = 1,34,139.

Corporate Accounting.question: During 2016-2017, Stock of Finished Goods on 01.04.2016 is ₹4,20,000; Purchase of Finished Goods ₹51,30,000; Stock of Finished Goods on 31.03.2017 is ₹6,00,000. Find 'Change in Inventories of Finished Goods' in P&L.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Change = Closing - Opening = 6,00,000 - 4,20,000 = +1,80,000. In P&L shown as (1,80,000).

Corporate Accounting.question: The balance in Share Forfeiture Account is ______
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Share Forfeiture A/c is transferred to Capital Reserve under Reserves & Surplus.

Corporate Accounting.question: Arrears of Preference Dividend are shown as
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Arrears of Preference Dividend are not an actual liability, they are disclosed as Contingent Liability.

Corporate Accounting.question:
Calculate Tax Payable / Tax Refund:
Gross Tax Liability AY 2016–2017 = ₹1,00,000. Advance Tax paid PY 2015–2016 = ₹1,40,000; PY 2016–2017 = ₹2,00,000.

Calculate adjusted profit for the year 2017-2018 from the following details: Profit before Tax: ₹1,50,000; Closing stock was undervalued by ₹10,000 in 2017-2018; Non-Recurring Income amounted to ₹4,500 and Tax rate applicable is 30.9%.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Adjusted Profit = 1,50,000 + 10,000 - 4,500 = ₹1,55,500 (before tax). After applying tax 30.9% ≈ ₹1,04,750.

Corporate Accounting.question: If normal profit is ₹ 60,000 and return on capital employed is 15%, then find out the amount of average capital employed.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Average Capital Employed = Normal Profit ÷ Rate of Return = 60,000 ÷ 0.15 = ₹4,00,000.

Corporate Accounting.question: In case of joint stock company, the need for calculating of goodwill may arise ______.
options: When company is taken over by Government
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Goodwill valuation may be required for taxation, takeover, or share conversion, so answer is All of the above.

Corporate Accounting.question: The reward an organisation receives by selling its assets at a high rate of price beyond its fair value is
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Super profit is profit earned above normal expectation.

Corporate Accounting.question: ______ is the time between the acquisition of assets for processing and their realization in cash or cash equivalents.
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Operating Cycle is the period from raw material acquisition to cash realization.

Corporate Accounting.question: Format of Statement of Profit & Loss is Given in ______ of the Companies Act 2013.
options: Part III to Schedule I of Section 129
Part I to Schedule III of Section 129
Part IV to Schedule I of Section 129
Part II to Schedule III of Section 129
Corporate Accounting.explanation: As per Companies Act, format is Part I to Schedule III of Section 129.

Corporate Accounting.question: Company shall disclose by way of notes additional information regarding aggregate expenditure and income if it exceeds.
options: One per cent of the revenue from operations
One per cent of the revenue from operations or ₹ 1,00,000, whichever is higher
Corporate Accounting.explanation: Threshold = 1% of revenue or ₹1,00,000 whichever is higher.
